abstracts.cdata!:
The Eritrea Emergency Reconstruction
            Program Project has a satisfactory outcome, is likely to be
            sustainable, and has a modest institutional development
            impact. The performances of both the Bank and the Borrower
            are satisfactory. The lessons cited addressed issues of
            design and implementation, the management of multi-sector
            operations and donor coordination, sector-supporting
            strategies and actions, and the needs of the poor and
            gender. Specific lessons included: 1) the need for projects
            operating in post-conflict countries to build in flexibility
            with fungible resources, accessed based on justification, to
            be able to address unforeseeable needs and conditions
            adequately, as they occur during implementation; 2) giving
            consideration to separating fast implementing and disbursing
            interventions for restoration of livelihoods and to address
            emergency needs, from interventions that may tend to take
            longer and have a longer-term development impact. 3) the
            importance of access to markets and services for any
            economic and social recovery process; 4) mainstreaming
            project component implementation and incorporating component
            design into the agency's strategic plan in order to
            facilitate internalization and enhance ownership and
            sustainability; 5) having smaller and more focused projects
            that involve fewer implementing agencies; 6) harmonizing
            procedures using the same manual of procurement as
            reference, and with central financial management using one
            MIS and with general management under one responsible
            entity; 7) the need to consult with beneficiaries in
            identifying and finalizing needs and areas of support in
            order to start-up and implement activities; 8) providing
            minimal support to displaced families as an incentive for
            returning to villages; 9) adopting design and build options
            for implementing emergency road infrastructure improvements;
            10) ensuring that emergency operations that target the
            private sector include interventions and monitoring
            indicators that address immediate needs for jumpstarting the
            private sector's contribution to the economy, and also
            build sustainability into project design by targeting
            export-oriented activities; 11) narrower targeting of
            criteria embracing the poor in particular, such as increased
            employment or income, to better focus assistance; and 12)
            targeting the needs of the female members of the communities.
